p: The onset of epidemics during the 2009 influenza season exhibited the greatest synchrony. Famously, 2009 was dominated by the emergence of a novel influenza A/H1N1 virus that resulted in a global pandemic and displaced the previous lineage of A/H1N1 that had circulated in the human population since 1977. We found that the time from the 5 th to the 95 th percentile of locations to be infected was less than 10 weeks in 2009, compared to an average time of ~25 weeks for the other years studied here. In Australia, up to 65% of ILI clinical isolates tested positive for influenza A and by early July 2009, A/H1N1 accounted for 90% of influenza A isolates [ 17]. Indeed, following its initial detection in the United States in April 2009, pandemic A/H1N1 rapidly spread and genetically diversified throughout the global human population [ 18].
